title: How can we listen to what others are not saying? - Quora

response.answer_text: In a literal sense, this is not possible. However, if one were to simply transcribe a person’s speech, much of the meaning would be lost. Non-verbal communication, such as the expression on the person’s face, posture, gesturing, etc. provide important information about the emotional context of the message. The person’s tone of voice provides additional information about the person’s emotional state. When people started to discover text-based online communication years ago, they quickly noticed that not being able to hear or see the person on the other end greatly hampered communications. Often, it could be difficult to tell whether people in these forums were intending to be taken literally or if they were making jokes. It was hard to tell when people were upset, annoyed, frustrated, etc., unless they specifically mentioned it. An ad-hoc language of faces (“smilies”) drawn using punctuation marks developed to fill this need for an emotional shorthand. Another important technique is understanding the context behind what the person is saying, or “reading between the lines.” Is the remark atypical for the person, based on prior knowledge of the person’s personality? Is the remark unusual, based on circumstances? Taken as a whole, do the person’s remarks and body language seem to be intended to give clues to a deeper message?

We already know what they are not saying. We have to fill in the blanks. We could also pose questions that include certain controls to elicit what most people would include in any response, and open-ended inquiries calculated to elicit variable information. Then we pay attention to their answers. Also, if we encounter someone who has a puffy red face and eyes, instead of asking if they've been crying, we can ask if we can get them an allergy pill or decongestant. If they say they don't have a cold or allergies, they're probably crying. No need to ask.
